rationale: FinPos provides implementation-useful structure for position-aware LLM trading systems: persistent exposure state, dual-stage decision decomposition, and CVaR-constrained sizing with multi-timescale reward shaping. However, autonomous production viability is not established because statistical uncertainty quantification is limited, execution-friction realism is incomplete, reproducibility manifests are not exhaustive, and external validity is constrained by single-asset framing and prompt sensitivity.
rejection_reasons: Reject immediate autonomous live deployment due to missing production-grade fees/slippage/latency/impact assumptions in headline evaluations.
Reject production promotion without confidence intervals and stronger repeated-window robustness analysis.
Reject broad generalization claims from current single-asset setup and limited stock universe.
Reject high-stakes deployment until deterministic replay manifests (data/prompt/config lineage) are complete.
recommendations: Implement FinPos as a reproducible research harness with explicit position-state accounting and auditable decision traces.
Add deterministic manifests: prompt hashes, data snapshot hashes, model/runtime pins, and run provenance metadata.
Re-run all baselines under identical friction-aware assumptions and standardized prompt/output constraints.
Require walk-forward multi-regime testing with uncertainty intervals before any deployment expansion.
Restrict operational mode to analyst-assist or paper trading with hard risk controls and manual oversight.
follow_up_actions: Reproduce Table 1 and Table 2 exactly from fully versioned inputs and verify metric consistency.
Add transaction costs, spread, slippage, and latency models; recompute CR/SR/MDD deltas.
Run regime-stratified evaluations (bull, bear, sideways) with confidence intervals.
Extend single-asset logic to constrained portfolio simulation with exposure/concentration limits.
Resolve baseline comparability inconsistencies between implementation-details text and architecture table.
